title: Passiflora actinia
text:
Passiflora actinia, also known as the sea anemone passion flower is a species of <a href="passion%20flower">passion flower</a> (<a href="https%3A//www.healthline.com/nutrition/passion-fruit">passionfruit</a>) of the <a href="Passifloraceae">Passifloraceae</a>. It flowers mainly in early <a href="spring%20%28season%29">spring</a>, producing white, mauve (purple), and blue flowers about 9 cm wide.
"Passiflora actinia" is an <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> <a href="vine">vine</a>. Native to Brazil, it is a relatively cold tolerant passion flower, and can be seen in gardens in England. Its edible fruit (a <a href="Passion%20fruit%20%28fruit%29">passionfruit</a>) is golden orange when ripe, and about 10 cm long. Passion fruit is a good source of nutrients, especially fiber, vitamin C, and provitamin A.
A single purple passion fruit contains (1Trusted Source):
Its specific name might be in reference to the scientific name of the <a href="sea%20anemones">sea anemones</a> (Actiniara), since it resembles one.
